Comment: Not every vaccine is placebo controlled. For example, if a known good vaccine already exists, it's often considered unethical to require the control group to use a placebo, since you'd be exposing them to a potentially harmful disease. Instead, the control group uses the existing standard. This is a way to test new and potentially improved versions of vaccines.  Then there are diseases where the vaccine has to be updated regularly. The flu shot being the most well known example. There simply isn't time to formulate the vaccine for the upcoming flu season, do a full placebo controlled test, then manufacture and distribute. Since the annual changes are minor and the process behind the vaccine is well understood, such vaccines are often allowed to use a simplified, faster process to get approved.

Comment: This is for vaccine testing, though, not like broad application.  Let's not fear-monger.  It's not that you'll go to get your flu shot and they'll give you saline instead.  It's that new vaccines will be tested against "no vaccine" where they may previously have been tested against "current vaccine".  So, imagine we somehow needed a new polio vaccine.  We would test it against the current vaccine to see if it's better, because the polio vaccine is effective and widely available to the vast majority of people.  The alternative is we find people without polio immunization, give some of them the new vaccine and others nothing, and then *expose them to polio*.  Odds are pretty good that the people without the vaccine are going to get polio and become critically ill (possibly with lifelong resulting disabilities) or die.  If there is no current vaccine then it's easy.  You're comparing the vaccine to what is already available - nothing.  If there is a current vaccine but it's not available to a demographic (because of cost or other factors), or it's only minimally effective, that's also fairly easy to justify because they're unlikely to have the benefits of a vaccine.  They effectively have "no current vaccine".  It's when you get to the level of "there is a current vaccine and it's both effective and accessible to a huge number of people" that it becomes sticky because you're essentially denying some people existing, available treatment to measure efficacy.
